content: the sock a little short than too long as you can knit some additional rounds working mc between the gusset markers if needed to obtain required length depending on your personal requirements decide how many gusset increases you need for fit remembering that stranded colour work is not as stretchy as non-stranded colour work choose the corresponding gusset chart to work the gusset and heel instructions will work regardless of which gusset chart you work stitch counts given in the pattern are based on gusset increases of 32 36 40 sts so if you work more/less increases your stitch count will differ if your row gauge differs from the pattern you will need to recalculate the above measurement for your row gauge see how to calculate on the next page this pattern is for personal use only ©lorraine rayson 2024 s-64 m-72 l-80 searching for king sexred-toe up-v01-230824 page 6 / 27 how to calculate when to start the gusset if your row gauge differs from pattern row gauge step 1 calculate your row gauge measure your row gauge over 2 5 cm/1 inch of stranded colour work step 2 divide the number of gusset row∆ 33 37 41 by your row gauge for metric multiple the number you get by 2 5 step 3 add 4 cm/1 5 inches for heel turn and negative ease to the measurement obtained in step 2 step 4 subtract the number obtained in step 3 from foot length and this is where you start the gusset ∆ note the number of row to calculate the gusset length is the number of row in the gusset chart plus 2 additional row see example 2 for how the row gauge is calculated step-by-step on p 10 gusset the centre sole stripe stitches are now incorporated into the gusset chart round 1 work as established to gm1 sm work gusset chart row 1 sm work as established to end of round 2 sts increase make a note of which motif chart and row you have just worked __________ for sock 2 round 2 work as established to gm1 sm work next row of gusset chart sm continue to end of round repeat round 2 until you have completed
